entry.title: Constructing Agents for Connect-4: Board Representations
entry.content:
This post is the 3rd part of a series of 7 articles:

  1. Constructing Agents for Connect-4: Initial Notes
  2. Constructing Agents for Connect-4: Tree Search Algorithms
  3. Constructing Agents for Connect-4: Board Representations
  4. Constructing Agents for Connect-4: Move Ordering
  5. Constructing Agents for Connect-4: Transposition Tables
  6. Constructing Agents for Connect-4: Opening Databases
  7. Constructing Agents for Connect-4: Final Considerations

The representation of the board is an elementary component of the agent. Since very large parts of the program require this data structure as a basis, special care must be taken in the specification of this data structure. This applies in particular to tree-search procedures such as the alpha-beta search, in which a large number of operations are performed on this data structure. Probably the simplest representation of the board is achieved in most games by using a one- or two-dimensional array. For Connect-4, for example, a 7x6 integer matrix could be used. This approach is also recommended for less complex games such as Tic Tac Toe, since efficiency is not particularly important and the representation of the board simplifies programming in many parts.

  Note: The related Java framework for Connect-4 is available on GitHub and can be downloaded from: http://github.com/MarkusThill/Connect-Four.

For more complex games such as Connect-4, Nine-Mens-Morris, Checkers or Chess, such a representation is often inconvenient. In these games, great importance must be attached to the efficiency of the algorithms and the underlying data structures. Reducing the Minimax or Alpha-Beta algorithm to the most basic operations quickly reveals that field manipulations (performing / undoing moves) and the identification of terminal states (win / loss or draw) play a central role. These operations all take place on the data structure of the game board. For the game Connect-4, the search for wins or losses (closed four-member chains), which takes place in practically all nodes of the game tree, can become an agent’s bottleneck. Especially this search for closed chains of four is comparatively complex when using arrays, especially if they have to be executed many millions of times in a certain time. For this reason, so-called bit boards were used for our alpha-beta agent, which have some basic advantages over simple arrays. Above all, the time-critical search for chains of four can be carried out efficiently with the help of this representation.

Bit Boards

In chess programming bit boards (often in combination with simple arrays) have been used for a long time to represent the board. In particular, the number of 64 fields in the chessboard makes the use of bit boards interesting, since most systems now have 64-bit architectures and 64-bit variables can be processed directly with a CPU instruction. Games like Othello or Checkers with 64 fields could also benefit from this. Basically, bit boards are simple variables, but they are considered at the bit level. Usually, the individual bits of a variable correspond to a position on the board. By setting or deleting the bits, individual pieces can be placed or removed at the corresponding position. In order to save some time during the tree search, it makes sense to use predefined masks. The runtime advantages that result from this are not to be underestimated. Since bit boards do not contain any information about the type of piece, only pieces of the same type can be held in a bit board. For example, when playing chess, all the white player’s pawn could be kept in a 64-bit variable, but not bishops which needed their own bit board. Connect-4 knows only two types of tiles, which means that two bit boards (one for each player) are needed. Each bit board requires 42 bits. It is therefore advisable to use 64-bit variables (e. g. of type Double or Long in Java) which use the least significant 42 bit (as in this project). Two 64-bit variables are therefore sufficient to completely describe a Connect-4 position. Placing a tile can be done with the help of a bitwise OR operation, deleting with a bitwise AND operation. Only the current ply is relevant for the recognition of a winning position. As a result, only a local search for chains of four in the surroundings of the occupied cell is necessary. Based on some bitwise AND operations performed on the player’s bit board and the corresponding bit masks (one for each possible string of four) any quads can be determined quickly. In our work, the winning search is implemented in a similar way, with the exception that the inverted bit boards are used here. However, the number of AND operations depends on the placement of the tile. Generally speaking, it can be said that more operations are required for central fields than for external ones, since in principle more potential chains of four are possible in the central fields.

The implementation of the data structures and the important operations can be found in the class CFour/src/c4/ConnectFour, which is also listed in the appendix of this post.

A few Examples

Board representation for Connect-4, using 3 variables

Performing a move:

Undoing a move:

Check, if position is a draw:

Mirror the board along the center column (called once for each player):

Advantages and Disadvantages of Bit Boards

Altogether, a number of advantages of bitboards over arrays can be identified (related to the game Connect-4; not all advantages are necessarily transferable to other games):

  • Many operations can be carried out more efficiently, since they can include several fields of the board at the same time. Examples are the recognition of winning positions and draws, the mirroring of playing boards along the middle column and the determination of threats.
  • Copying the board can be done much faster because only two 64-bit variables represent the board.
  • Reduced memory requirements associated with transposition tables.

However, the use of bit boards can have some disadvantages that should not be neglected:

  • High programming effort: In some cases, parts of the source code were also generated with other programs.
  • Poor readability of the source code.
  • Maintenance of the program is difficult.
  • Fault-prone and tedious troubleshooting.
  • Very long program code: All in all, nearly 7000 lines of source code were needed to realize this agent.

Appendix

This Github Sample is by MarkusThill
CFour/src/c4/ConnectFour.java view raw

entry.title: Constructing Agents for Connect-4: Tree Search Algorithms
entry.content:
This post is the 2nd part of a series of 7 articles:

  1. Constructing Agents for Connect-4: Initial Notes
  2. Constructing Agents for Connect-4: Tree Search Algorithms
  3. Constructing Agents for Connect-4: Board Representations
  4. Constructing Agents for Connect-4: Move Ordering
  5. Constructing Agents for Connect-4: Transposition Tables
  6. Constructing Agents for Connect-4: Opening Databases
  7. Constructing Agents for Connect-4: Final Considerations

For Connect-4, a perfectly playing agent must be able to fully examine the game tree (in extreme cases 42 moves), but the search effort increases exponentially with the search depth, so that in many respects a high development effort is necessary to achieve this goal. This post and the following are intended to explain some of the procedures and techniques used to enable such an agent. In this blog post, we will particularly look at a basic tree search algorithm: the alpha-beta search.

  Note: The related Java framework for Connect-4 is available on GitHub and can be downloaded from: http://github.com/MarkusThill/Connect-Four.

The Alpha-Beta Search

The Alpha-Beta search is a tree-search algorithm based on the classic Minimax algorithm, which has been optimized in some parts. While a simple Minimax search examines all nodes of the game tree, using two variables (alpha and beta) in the alpha-beta search may cut off large subtrees during the search. However, the number and extent of cutoffs depend on several factors such as the quality of the move ordering. The basic idea behind the algorithm is as follows: Since the opponents, due to their maximizing or minimizing behavior, avoid certain game courses if they are already aware of better alternatives, the investigation of whole subtrees is unnecessary, since certain plies would not be considered anyway. As already mentioned, two variables play a central role: Alpha describes the lower bound of the maximizing player and corresponds to the value that this player will reach at least at the moment. The variable Beta, on the other hand, contains the upper bound of the minimizing player and indicates the maximum value that is reached by the minimizing player. Due to the recursive nature of the alpha-beta algorithm, the alpha and beta values in each node of the tree can be changed and compared with the current values, so that cutoffs are not limited to the root node, but can be made at any point in the tree. From the maximizing player’s point of view, the following steps are taken to process a tree node: First of all, the search determines all possible legal moves that are then successively tested. If the search returns a value greater than or equal to Beta for one of the following states, the current node is immediately exited and Beta is returned. This is a fail-high. The returned value corresponds to a lower bound of the actual game-theoretical value of the position. A fail-low occurs in a node when Alpha has not yet been adjusted a single time and therefore no move could improve the existing result. When leaving the node, the routine returns Alpha, the upper bound for the exact value of the position. Only values between alpha and beta are exact, in all other cases only bounds are determined, because the precise values for the outcome of the game are not relevant. In his introduction to chess programming, Bruce Moreland describes the above facts very succinctly and comprehensively:

“A fail-high indicates that the search found something that was “too good”. What this means is that the opponent has some way, already found by the search, of avoiding this position, so you have to assume that they’ll do this. If they can avoid this position, there is no longer any need to search successors, since this position won’t happen. A fail-low indicates that this position was not good enough for us. We will not reach this position, because we have some other means of reaching a position that is better. We will not make the move that allowed the opponent to put us in this position. Minimizing nodes can be inspected in the same way as the aforementioned.”

Details can be found in the simplified pseudo code listed in the following or in the source code (c4. AlphaBetaAgent) in the appendix. Certain elements of the pseudo-code are also explained in later blog posts.

Appendix

This Github Sample is by MarkusThill
CFour/src/c4/AlphaBetaAgent.java view raw

Note: Several paragraphs of this blog post are in parts taken from my Master’s thesis or from a translation of my Bachelor thesis and some earlier project work.

Constructing Agents for Connect-4: Tree Search Algorithms was originally published by Markus Thill at ML & Stats on February 12, 2018.

entry.title: Constructing Agents for Connect-4: Initial Notes
entry.content:
This post is the 1st part of a series of 7 articles:

  1. Constructing Agents for Connect-4: Initial Notes
  2. Constructing Agents for Connect-4: Tree Search Algorithms
  3. Constructing Agents for Connect-4: Board Representations
  4. Constructing Agents for Connect-4: Move Ordering
  5. Constructing Agents for Connect-4: Transposition Tables
  6. Constructing Agents for Connect-4: Opening Databases
  7. Constructing Agents for Connect-4: Final Considerations

The study of strategic board games is one of the classical research areas in the field of artificial intelligence (AI). In countless works, the most diverse approaches have been and are being investigated, which are often very different in their objectives. Especially complex games such as chess, Go or checkers seem to be of particular interest from the perspective of research. In this blog post and in the following posts, we will take a look at the game Connect-4 and explore different ways for the construction of a strong player using AI methods.

  Note: The related Java framework for Connect-4 is available on GitHub and can be downloaded from: http://github.com/MarkusThill/Connect-Four.

Introduction

For many years now, researchers have been working on the question of whether and to what extent machines will ever be able to achieve a degree of intelligence similar to human intelligence. Many branches of research are concerned with the development of intelligent machines and computer programs that are designed to solve certain problems. In this context, the term artificial intelligence (AI) is often used. However, an exact or general definition of the term is difficult, since already when describing intelligence in general, very different views are taken. The well-known American computer scientist John McCarthy described the “artificial intelligence” as follows:

“It is the science and engineering of making intelligent machines, especially intelligent computer programs. It is related to the similar task of using computers to understand human intelligence, but AI does not have to confine itself to methods that are biologically observable.”

In particular, the study and learning of strategic board games using computer programs has always played a prominent role from the point of view of research. A large number of studies - with the most various goals and solutions - in the last 70 years have been dealing extensively with the development of machine players. Particular attention was paid to the game of chess. Already in 1769, Wolfgang von Kempelen, an Austrian-Hungarian civil servant, achieved fame with his “Mechanical Turk”. This was a machine that was supposedly able to play chess against human opponents with the help of a complex mechanism. Only later it turned out that a small human being could be hidden inside the machine, who used a special device to perform the moves. The author of the first chess program is Konrad Zuse, who developed his program in the years 1942 to 1945 - using the self-designed programming language Plankalkül. Since then, a great deal has happened in the field of artificial intelligence. The development reached a new peak with the victory of Deep Blue - a chess computer from IBM - against the reigning chess world champion Garri Kasparov. However, the enormous playing capability was achieved with the help of a massively parallel system, which was able to examine more than 2 million board positions per second.

Board games are not without reason one of the oldest and most researched areas of AI, some features make them particularly interesting for research: Most strategic board games have a clear set of rules and a clearly defined goal (terminating condition; endlessly long games are generally not possible) that usually doesn’t change during the game. The rules and regulations can therefore normally be learned very easily or implemented in a program. Nevertheless, it is often not possible to achieve the desired goal (e. g. “checkmating” of the opponent) without difficulty, since a whole series of actions is necessary for this; therefore, a statement about victory, defeat and draw can only be made after a sequence of actions. Although the set of rules limits the number of possible actions per move, non-trivial games can have an astronomically large number of possible move sequences, so that even a computer with massive performance cannot easily examine all combinations. Due to the enormous complexity of many games, a certain form of intelligence is therefore required to achieve acceptable playing strength. Another point that distinguishes classic board games (with a few exceptions) from many other problems is that the complete environment (the board) is known at any moment of the game and also how individual actions affect the condition of the board. Furthermore, the discrete game states of most board games simplify the implementation of the different algorithms.

An outstanding skill of the human being is that in many situations he is able to recognize certain characteristics or patterns and create similarities with other situations. For example, a person has no problem identifying known faces in a photo because he can memorize essential facial features and recall and compare them if necessary. Even in board games, people can quickly recognize certain interrelationships and apply them successfully to new game situations. In the field of AI, it is much more difficult to recognize such patterns and to combine them in a suitable way to learn a game. Therefore, in the past, tree search methods were used very often and attempts were made to optimize the important parts (pruning of sub-trees etc.). However, such programs cannot “learn” the game in the classical sense of the word, but can simply search through a huge number of game situations in order to make an allegedly intelligent statement. Many machine learning processes also depend on external “features” that tell the program which characteristics are of particular importance for the learning process. However, the selection and combination of suitable features is not trivial and often requires a high degree of creativity.

A suitable machine learning approach to learning strategic board games is Reinforcement Learning – especially Temporal Difference Learning (TDL) – where an agent tries to determine the usefulness of action sequences. After the end of the training games, the agent receives - depending on the outcome of the game - different rewards. In this way, the use of individual action sequences can be learned backwards during a certain number of training games. An important aspect here is the modeling of the value function, which is mainly required for position evaluation and ultimately for the assessment of individual actions.

But let us start first with classical search-tree-based approaches, before we move on to machine learning techniques in some later blog posts.

Connect-4

Connect-4 is a popular board game for two players (typically Yellow and Red) played on a grid with seven columns and six rows. Initially, the board is completely empty so that 42 free positions are available. One main characteristic of the game is the vertical arrangement of the board, which restricts both players to only dropping their pieces into one of the seven columns (slots). Starting with Yellow, both players in turn drop one of their pieces into a slot of their choice. Under the force of gravity, the pieces then fall down to the lowest free position of the respective slot. If all six positions of a slot are occupied, it is not possible to place further pieces into this slot and the number of possible moves for both players is reduced by one. Both opponents attempt to create a continuous line of four adjacent pieces with their color, either horizontally, vertically or, diagonally. The player who can achieve this first, wins the game. If none of the opponents is able to create a line of four with his own pieces during the 42 moves match, all columns will be completely filled and – according to the rules – the match ends with a tie. An example position for Connect-4 is shown in the below figure.

Although Connect-4 has a medium state space complexity of around different positions [1] and a game-tree complexity of approximately [2], solving the game remains a non-trivial task until today. The first solution was independently found by Allen [3] and Allis [4] in 1988. In their work the game was weakly solved; both could show – assuming perfect play of both opponents – that Yellow wins the game if she places her first piece in the center slot. Red on the other hand, can delay her defeat as far as possible to the end and force Yellow to use all her pieces. In 1994, Tromp [5] completed a database containing the game-theoretic values (win/loss/draw) of all non-trivial (Remark: Tromp considered all positions with an immediate threat as trivial. This may be true for positions with an immediate threat for Yellow, since she can win with her next move. However, immediate threats for Red can be neutralized by Yellow and the match would continue normally. This definition of triviality is therefore not completely correct.) positions with exactly 8 pieces, which strongly solved Connect-4. The evaluation of all positions took him around hours ( years).

In the following table, the number of leaf nodes and the state space complexity for a given number of plies is shown. With a maximum of 12 pieces (after 12 plies), the state space complexity is still about a factor of smaller than that of the complete game with up to 42 pieces (last value taken from [1]). The source code for computing this table can be found in the appendix and on GitHub.

A Connect-4 Agent based on Tree-Search Techniques:

Summary of the following Blog Posts

Some time ago I developed a perfect playing Connect-4 agent. I started with a simple MiniMax (simple tree search) agent and optimized the algorithm little by little. The resulting agent is based on advanced tree-search algorithms and is supported by extensive databases to master the opening phase of the game. For Connect-4 we can make use of Tromp’s 8-ply opening-database. I extended Tromp’s database by all 8-ply positions with an immediate threat for yellow, since all positions with immediate threats were missing. Additionally, I generated a Huffman-encoded database containing all positions with 12 pieces, the expected outcome and the exact distance to the end of the game, assuming perfect play of both opponents. The tree-search (MiniMax algorithm) in Connect-4 is enhanced by alpha-beta pruning, move-ordering mechanisms, symmetries, two-stage transposition tables in order to identify identical positions created by permutations of a certain move sequence, Zobrist Hashing, Enhanced Transposition Cutoffs and more.

As the main underlying data-structure for the board-representation of Connect-4 so called bit-boards are used. In this representation, each board cell (in Connect-4) can be represented by two bits in a bit-field. In total, bit are required to represent a Connect-4 position (42 bit per player). If a suitable arrangement of all board cells in the bit-field is chosen, then many operations can be performed efficiently, since a modern CPU already provides many fast bit-wise instructions (AND, OR, XOR, bit- and byte-wise inversion, etc.). Frequently recurring operations on a board typically are: placing and removing pieces, mirroring and rotation, copying, identifying win/loss/draw situations and others. Many of these mentioned operations can be executed faster with bit-boards than with conventional data-structures such as arrays. For example, in Connect-4, the recognition of terminal states (4 pieces in a row) is a time-critical operation, for which an efficient solution by using bit-boards could be found. Another advantage of bit-boards is the memory-efficiency, which is especially beneficial when many board positions have to be stored in transposition tables. Overall, our MiniMax agent for Connect-4 is one of the fastest perfect-playing agents available: the empty board can be analyzed in less than 4 minutes on a Pentium-4 computer, without the support of the opening-database and using only a 24 MB transposition table. In the typical setup – with the 12-ply opening-database and a 24 MB transposition table – MiniMax can analyze each board position in fractions of a second.

These techniques will be explained in more details in the next couple of blog posts.

Connect-4 Java Framework

A software framework for Connect-4 in Java is available on GitHub, which allows to conduct and perform learning experiments. A GUI is available, which provides visual inspection capabilities, evaluation tools, import/export functionalities, direct interaction between user and various agents (random, TDL, Minimax, Monte Carlo tree search) and more. The Java framework for Connect-4 is available as open source from GitHub and can be downloaded from: http://github.com/MarkusThill/Connect-Four.
